content.question: The graph of the polar curve <math alttext="r equals theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown above for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to theta, less than or equal to 3 pi" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. What is the area of the shaded region?

choices.label: <math alttext="the fraction with numerator pi cubed, and denominator 6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="the fraction with numerator 19 times pi cubed, and denominator 6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>19</mn><msup><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="the fraction with numerator 9 times pi cubed, and denominator 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>9</mn><msup><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.9: (BC ONLY) Finding the Area of the Region Bounded by Two Polar Curves
